questions.text: IOC for localization of PTH adenoma
questions.solution:
High-resolution sonography and 99mTc sestamibi scintigraphy are the main imaging techniques for preoperative location of parathyroid adenomas with similar sensitivities and specificities for solitary adenoma detection by these techniques.

Nuclear medicine computer subtraction images of thallium and technetium can aid in the localization of the abnormal parathyroid gland. This technique relies on the differential uptake of the two isotopes by the thyroid and parathyroid glands. Thallium-201 chloride accumulates in tissues with high blood flow which includes both thyroid and parathyroid glands as well as in thyroid nodules and parathyroid adenomas. 99mTechnetium accumulates only in the thyroid. Digital images are produced with each isotope. The technetium scan is then subtracted from the thallium leaving an image of only the parathyroid concentration of thallium. The radiopharmaceutical of choice for imaging parathyroid enlargement is 99mTc sestamibi. 99mTc sestamibi has replaced 201Tl for parathyroid scintigraphy because of superior image quality, more favorable dosimetry, and improved detection sensitivity with its use.

Other Options:

(A) CT scan:

  • Use: A 4D-CT scan is sometimes used for localization of a parathyroid adenoma, particularly when a Sestamibi scan is inconclusive.
  • Advantages: Provides excellent anatomical details and can detect ectopic adenomas.
  • Disadvantages: Involves radiation exposure and may not be as sensitive as Sestamibi in some cases.

(C) MRI:

  • Use: Rarely used as a primary imaging tool but may be helpful in certain cases (e.g., ectopic adenomas or reoperative cases).
  • Advantages: No radiation exposure and good soft tissue contrast.
  • Disadvantages: More expensive, time-consuming, and not as widely available for routine parathyroid localization.

(D) FDG-PET:

  • Use: Generally not the first choice for routine localization of parathyroid adenomas. However, choline PET-CT (not FDG-PET) is emerging as a promising alternative, especially in cases of persistent or recurrent hyperparathyroidism.
  • Advantages: May detect adenomas missed by conventional imaging.
  • Disadvantages: Costly and not widely available.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2872

It is important to detect the exact cause of CMP as this determines the treatment and the patient survival. Echocardiography (ECHO) and radionuclide imaging alone cannot determine the exact etiology due to inadequate myocardial assessment (inferior spatial and contrast resolution and limited tissue characterization). Catheter angiography assesses only chamber lumen, with poor demonstration of myocardial changes. Also, significant overlap of features between CMPs frequently exists. Thus, endomyocardial biopsy remains the gold standard technique for diagnosis of myocarditis.

A value of >14 leukocytes/mm(2) with the presence of T lymphocytes >7 cells/mm(2) has been considered a realistic cut off to reach a diagnosis of myocarditis

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2612

questions.text: A 45 year old female having HIV prescribed ergotamine for migraine attacks, developed acute pain in mid-thigh with non-palpable dorsalis pedis. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ergotamine has been used widely for the treatment of migraine. Ergotism is a sustained vasospasm induced by ergot medication, and is very rare, but has been observed in various situations, mainly as a result of ergotamine overuse, idiosyncratic hypersensitivity reaction with therapeutic doses, and during concomitant use of other kinds of medication. The given angiographic images shows non opacification of the peripheral vessels which is suggestive of reduced blood flow. In patient with history of ergotamine, it is suggestive of vasospasm/ ergotism.

Reference: Jeong SY, Lim ES, Shin BS, Seo MW, Kim YH, Kwak HS, Chung GH, Jeong SK. Ergotism with ischemia in all four extremities: a case report. J Clin Neurol. 2006 Dec;2(4):279-82. doi: 10.3988/jcn.2006.2.4.279. Epub 2006 Dec 20. PMID: 20396534; PMCID: PMC2854981.

questions.text: Identify the modality shown here
questions.solution:
The given image shows CT scan of abdomen in 3 dimensional projections. Bone is appearing white in CT.

  • Uses X-rays to create cross-sectional images.
  • Appears in grayscale, with bones being white, soft tissues in various shades of gray, and air appearing black.
  • Often used for evaluating the brain, chest, abdomen, and bones.

Other options:

(B)Dye Study

  • Could refer to contrast-enhanced imaging such as a barium swallow, IV urography, or fluoroscopy using a contrast agent.
  • Typically used for evaluating the GI tract or urinary system.
  • Images may have a bright white contrast-filled structure against a dark background

(C) Angiography

  • A specialized study focusing on blood vessels using contrast dye and X-ray/CT/MRI.
  • Blood vessels appear bright (white) against a darker background.
  • Used to diagnose conditions like aneurysms, blockages, or vascular malformations.

(D) MRI

  • Uses magnetic fields and radio waves, not X-rays.
  • Better for soft tissue differentiation (brain, spinal cord, joints).
  • Often appears in T1/T2-weighted grayscale images, with fluids appearing bright (T2) or dark (T1).

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1646

questions.text: A 35 year old female presents with abdominal pain on post-op day 5 following laparoscopic cholecystectomy. USG showed a collection in the RUQ. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
The given findings show a possibility of bile leak following surgery. The investigation to be done in such cases would be a HIDA scan and the management would be to drain the bile collected with Pig tail insertion under USG guidance.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 861

questions.text: Identify the marked structure
questions.solution:
The given image is a coronal CT scan of the paranasal sinuses and orbits, showing bony structures. The arrows are pointing to small bony canals located at the superior medial portion of the orbit, just lateral to the cribriform plate.

Correct Answer: (A) Anterior Ethmoid Canal

(A) Anterior Ethmoid Canal (Correct Answer)

  • The anterior ethmoidal canal carries the anterior ethmoidal artery, vein, and nerve from the orbit to the anterior cranial fossa.
  • It is located at the superior-medial orbital wall, traversing from the orbit to the cribriform plate.
  • The arrows in the image are pointing at small bony canals in this exact location.

Other options:

(B) Posterior Ethmoid Canal

  • Lies posterior to the anterior ethmoid canal and is usually smaller.
  • It transmits the posterior ethmoidal artery and nerve.
  • Less commonly visualized in coronal CT unless specifically focused.

(C) Cribriform Plate

  • Part of the ethmoid bone forming the roof of the nasal cavity.
  • Contains multiple small foramina for the passage of olfactory nerve fibers (CN I).
  • The marked structure in the image is lateral to the cribriform plate, making this option incorrect.

(D) Superior Orbital Fissure

  • Located laterally in the orbit, between the greater and lesser wings of the sphenoid.
  • Transmits cranial nerves III, IV, V1, and VI, along with the superior ophthalmic vein.
  • The marked structure is too medial to be the superior orbital fissure.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 3736

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Anencephaly is a condition in which there is absence of cranial vault and much of the brain parenchyma. The residual brain parenchyma is grossly malformed. It occurs due to failure of closure of anterior neuropore around 24 days of gestation. Most cases are diagnosed early by a combination of ultrasound and maternal AFP levels. On ultrasound, the fetal face has frog like appearance with prominent orbits due to absence of frontal bones.

Others options:

  • (B) Omphalocele - A congenital abdominal wall defect where the intestines and sometimes other organs protrude outside the abdomen but are covered by a membrane.
  • (C) Cystic Hygroma - A fluid-filled sac resulting from lymphatic malformation, commonly found in the neck region.
  • (D) Encephalocele - A neural tube defect where brain tissue protrudes through an opening in the skull but differs from anencephaly as some brain structures are still present.

Reference: Clinical Ultrasound, Volume 3, page no 302

questions.text: Identify the MRI sequence
questions.solution:
The given images shows SWI images where we can differentiate between blood and calcium. It is used to identify hemorrhagic transformation in stroke patients, small microhemorrhages and to help diagnose hypertensive and amyloid angiopathy.

Other options:

(B) Proton Density (PD): This sequence provides a balance between T1 and T2 contrast, primarily used in musculoskeletal and brain imaging for differentiating gray and white matter.

(C) ADC (Apparent Diffusion Coefficient): Part of diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI), ADC maps help assess tissue diffusivity and are crucial for detecting acute ischemic strokes.

(D) Gradient Echo (GRE): Sensitive to magnetic field inhomogeneities and used in detecting hemorrhages, but SWI is a more advanced technique that provides higher sensitivity in detecting small bleeds and venous structures

Reference: MRI MADE EASY page 70

questions.text: A 5 year old child with intermittent pain presents with the following CXR. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Congenital diaphragmatic hernia signifies intrathoracic herniation of abdominal organs through a defect in the diaphragm.

The diaphragmatic defect may be located anteromedially (Morgagni hernia), posterolaterally (Bochdalek hernia), or in the central tendon of diaphragm.

The condition is being diagnosed increasingly during antenatal ultrasound which facilitates supervised institutional delivery.

The radiographic appearance depends on the contents of hernia sac and distension of bowel. If radiograph is acquired early, the bowel may be fluid-filled or collapse resulting in opacity of variable size in lower hemithorax with contralateral mediastinal shift.

KEY TAKEAWAY- Radiological features of congenital diaphragmatic hernia on xray.

  • Bowel gas in the chest cavity.
  • Mediastinal shift.
  • Reduced lung volume on the side of the hernia

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 999

questions.text: A patient presents with a renal lesion with thick walls and septations s/o bosniak 3. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Bosniak classification is a system to classify the cystic renal masses into benign and malignant and is based on CT appearance of the lesion.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no110

questions.text: A patient presents with cough and hemoptysis since 10 days. CXR shows a lesion in right lung field with ipsilateral tracheal deviation. What is the next line of Mx?
questions.solution:
The given xray shows a lesion in the right upper zone with an ipsilateral mediastinal shift. These features are highly suggestive of a lesion with malignant nature. To diagnose, the preferred approach would be a bronchoscopy guided biopsy.

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Disgnostic Radiology, sixth edition, page no 333

questions.text: A 48 year old lady presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain. USG reveal multiple GB calculi but no wall thickening, CBD diameter 12cm, gamma glutamyl transferase 5 times increased, alkaline phosphate was high also 400 IU. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
MRCP is non invasive, should be performed before ERCP for proper management. The patient is showing signs of hepatitis with dilatation of the common bile duct and the next step would be ERCP/MRCP to look for an gall stone obstructing the bile duct and causing such symptoms and lab findings.

Reference: MRI made easy, second edition, page no 183.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presents to the casualty with right sided hemiparesis and aphasia for 2 hrs. An imaging is done and shown above. BP is 160/110 and random blood sugar is 106. NCCT is normal. Next step:
questions.solution:
The patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of stroke. The stroke protocol consists of NCCT, CTA and CT perfusion.

As the patient has Hemiparesis and Aphasia, we need to rule out large vessel occlusion by CT Angiography.

KEY TAKEAWAY- In cases of stroke first investigation is NCCT to rule out hemorrhagic stroke. After that CT angiography is done for localization.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2700
